file.content:
# Formalize Conjecture

To formalize conjecture NUM:

1. Read problem from `tidy/NUM.html`.
2. Formalize conjecture in lean and persist to `conjectures/NUM.lean`.
3. Build the file using the command `lake build conjectures/NUM.lean`.
4. Debug build until it runs successfully.

Documentation:

- Lean 4 docs: https://lean-lang.org/doc/reference/latest/
- Mathlib docs: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/

Things to consider:

- Note that build logs will throw warnings about sorry declarations. This is expected and fine for conjectures.

DISPROVED This has been solved in the negative. - $50
Let $A,B,C$ be three sets of cardinality $\aleph_1$. Is it true that, in any $2$-colouring of $A\times B\times C$, there must exist $A_1\subset A$, $B_1\subset B$, $C_1\subset C$, all of cardinality $\aleph_0$, such that $A_1\times B_1\times C_1$ is monochromatic?
#1128: [Er81b,p.33]
set theory | ramsey theory | hypergraphs
A problem of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal.

This was disproved by Prikry and Mills in 1978 but this seems to have been unpublished. This is reported by TodorÄeviÄ‡ [To94] and KomjÃ¡th [Ko25b].

     9â†’
    10â†’/-- A simple graph contains a 4-cycle (Câ‚„) if there exist four distinct vertices
    11â†’    a, b, c, d forming the cycle a-b-c-d-a. -/
    12â†’def ContainsCycleFour {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    13â†’  âˆƒ a b c d : V, a â‰  b âˆ§ a â‰  c âˆ§ a â‰  d âˆ§ b â‰  c âˆ§ b â‰  d âˆ§ c â‰  d âˆ§
    14â†’    G.Adj a b âˆ§ G.Adj b c âˆ§ G.Adj c d âˆ§ G.Adj d a
    15â†’
    16â†’/-- A simple graph is Câ‚„-free if it contains no 4-cycle as a subgraph. -/
    17â†’def CycleFourFree {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    18â†’  Â¬ContainsCycleFour G
    19â†’
    20â†’/--
    21â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #1008 (Proved by Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov [CFS14b]):
    22â†’There exists an absolute constant c > 0 such that every graph with m edges
    23â†’contains a Câ‚„-free subgraph with at least c Â· m^{2/3} edges.
    24â†’
    25â†’Originally asked by BollobÃ¡s and ErdÅ‘s with m^{3/4} in place of m^{2/3},
    26â†’but Folkman showed the m^{3/4} version is false. ErdÅ‘s [Er71] revised the
    27â†’conjecture to m^{2/3}, noting â‰« m^{1/2} is trivial.
    28â†’-/
    29â†’theorem erdos_problem_1008 :
    30â†’    âˆƒ c : â„, c > 0 âˆ§
    31â†’      âˆ€ (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)),
    32â†’        âˆƒ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    33â†’          H â‰¤ G âˆ§
    34â†’          CycleFourFree H âˆ§

file.content:
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real

noncomputable section

open SimpleGraph Classical

/-- A simple graph contains a 4-cycle (Câ‚„) if there exist four distinct vertices
    a, b, c, d forming the cycle a-b-c-d-a. -/
def ContainsCycleFour {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
  âˆƒ a b c d : V, a â‰  b âˆ§ a â‰  c âˆ§ a â‰  d âˆ§ b â‰  c âˆ§ b â‰  d âˆ§ c â‰  d âˆ§
    G.Adj a b âˆ§ G.Adj b c âˆ§ G.Adj c d âˆ§ G.Adj d a

/-- A simple graph is Câ‚„-free if it contains no 4-cycle as a subgraph. -/
def CycleFourFree {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
  Â¬ContainsCycleFour G

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #1008 (Proved by Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov [CFS14b]):
There exists an absolute constant c > 0 such that every graph with m edges
contains a Câ‚„-free subgraph with at least c Â· m^{2/3} edges.

Originally asked by BollobÃ¡s and ErdÅ‘s with m^{3/4} in place of m^{2/3},
but Folkman showed the m^{3/4} version is false. ErdÅ‘s [Er71] revised the
conjecture to m^{2/3}, noting â‰« m^{1/2} is trivial.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_1008 :
    âˆƒ c : â„, c > 0 âˆ§
      âˆ€ (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)),
        âˆƒ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
          H â‰¤ G âˆ§
          CycleFourFree H âˆ§
          c * (G.edgeFinset.card : â„) ^ ((2 : â„) / 3) â‰¤ (H.edgeFinset.card : â„) :=
  sorry

end

     2â†’import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.FiniteDimensional
     3â†’import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Dimension.Finrank
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     7â†’
     8â†’/--
     9â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #1090 (proved):
    10â†’Let k â‰¥ 3. Does there exist a finite set A âŠ‚ â„Â² such that, in any 2-colouring
    11â†’of A, there exists a line which contains at least k points from A, and all the
    12â†’points of A on the line have the same colour?
    13â†’
    14â†’The answer is yes. ErdÅ‘s [Er75f] notes that Graham and Selfridge proved the
    15â†’case k = 3. Hunter observed that for sufficiently large n, a generic projection
    16â†’of [k]^n into â„Â² has this property, by the Halesâ€“Jewett theorem.
    17â†’-/
    18â†’theorem erdos_problem_1090 (k : â„•) (hk : k â‰¥ 3) :
    19â†’    âˆƒ A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2)),
    20â†’      âˆ€ c : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2) â†’ Fin 2,
    21â†’        âˆƒ L : AffineSubspace â„ (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2)),
    22â†’          Module.finrank â„ L.direction = 1 âˆ§
    23â†’          k â‰¤ Set.ncard {p : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2) | p âˆˆ (A : Set _) âˆ§ p âˆˆ L} âˆ§
    24â†’          âˆƒ color : Fin 2, âˆ€ p âˆˆ (A : Set _), p âˆˆ L â†’ c p = color :=
    25â†’  sorry
    26â†’

file.content:
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.FiniteDimensional
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Dimension.Finrank
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #1090 (proved):
Let k â‰¥ 3. Does there exist a finite set A âŠ‚ â„Â² such that, in any 2-colouring
of A, there exists a line which contains at least k points from A, and all the
points of A on the line have the same colour?

The answer is yes. ErdÅ‘s [Er75f] notes that Graham and Selfridge proved the
case k = 3. Hunter observed that for sufficiently large n, a generic projection
of [k]^n into â„Â² has this property, by the Halesâ€“Jewett theorem.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_1090 (k : â„•) (hk : k â‰¥ 3) :
    âˆƒ A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2)),
      âˆ€ c : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2) â†’ Fin 2,
        âˆƒ L : AffineSubspace â„ (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2)),
          Module.finrank â„ L.direction = 1 âˆ§
          k â‰¤ Set.ncard {p : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2) | p âˆˆ (A : Set _) âˆ§ p âˆˆ L} âˆ§
          âˆƒ color : Fin 2, âˆ€ p âˆˆ (A : Set _), p âˆˆ L â†’ c p = color :=
  sorry

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     3â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     4â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     5â†’
     6â†’noncomputable section
     7â†’open SimpleGraph Classical Filter
     8â†’
     9â†’namespace Erdos1091
    10â†’
    11â†’/-- A graph G contains an odd cycle with at least `d` diagonals.
    12â†’
    13â†’An odd cycle of length 2m+3 (â‰¥ 3) is given by an injective map f : Fin (2m+3) â†’ V
    14â†’where consecutive vertices (cyclically) are adjacent in G. A diagonal is an edge
    15â†’of G between two cycle vertices that are not consecutive in the cycle. -/
    16â†’def HasOddCycleWithDiagonals {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) (d : â„•) : Prop :=
    17â†’  âˆƒ (m : â„•) (f : Fin (2 * m + 3) â†’ V),
    18â†’    Function.Injective f âˆ§
    19â†’    (âˆ€ i : Fin (2 * m + 3),
    20â†’      G.Adj (f i) (f âŸ¨(i.val + 1) % (2 * m + 3), Nat.mod_lt _ (by omega)âŸ©)) âˆ§
    21â†’    d â‰¤ (Finset.univ.filter (fun p : Fin (2 * m + 3) Ã— Fin (2 * m + 3) =>
    22â†’      p.1.val < p.2.val âˆ§
    23â†’      G.Adj (f p.1) (f p.2) âˆ§
    24â†’      p.2.val â‰  (p.1.val + 1) % (2 * m + 3) âˆ§
    25â†’      p.1.val â‰  (p.2.val + 1) % (2 * m + 3))).card
    26â†’
    27â†’/--
    28â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #1091, Part 1 (proved by Voss [Vo82]):
    29â†’
    30â†’Let G be a Kâ‚„-free graph with chromatic number 4. Then G contains an odd cycle
    31â†’with at least two diagonals.
    32â†’
    33â†’ErdÅ‘s originally asked about one diagonal, proved by Larson [La79]. The
    34â†’pentagonal wheel shows that three diagonals cannot be guaranteed.
    35â†’-/
    36â†’theorem erdos_problem_1091a (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n))
    37â†’    (hK4 : G.CliqueFree 4) (hÏ‡ : G.chromaticNumber = (4 : â„•âˆ)) :
    38â†’    HasOddCycleWithDiagonals G 2 :=
    39â†’  sorry
    40â†’
    41â†’/--
    42â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #1091, Part 2 (Open) [Er76c,p.4]:
    43â†’
    44â†’Is there a function f : â„• â†’ â„• with f(r) â†’ âˆ such that every graph G with
    45â†’chromatic number 4, in which every induced subgraph on â‰¤ r vertices has
    46â†’chromatic number â‰¤ 3, contains an odd cycle with at least f(r) diagonals?
    47â†’-/
    48â†’theorem erdos_problem_1091b :
    49â†’    âˆƒ f : â„• â†’ â„•, Tendsto f atTop atTop âˆ§
    50â†’      âˆ€ (r n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)),
    51â†’        G.chromaticNumber = (4 : â„•âˆ) â†’
    52â†’        (âˆ€ S : Finset (Fin n), S.card â‰¤ r â†’
    53â†’          (G.induce (â†‘S : Set (Fin n))).chromaticNumber â‰¤ (3 : â„•âˆ)) â†’
    54â†’        HasOddCycleWithDiagonals G (f r) :=
    55â†’  sorry
    56â†’
    57â†’end Erdos1091
    58â†’

file.content:
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic

noncomputable section
open SimpleGraph Classical Filter

namespace Erdos1091

/-- A graph G contains an odd cycle with at least `d` diagonals.

An odd cycle of length 2m+3 (â‰¥ 3) is given by an injective map f : Fin (2m+3) â†’ V
where consecutive vertices (cyclically) are adjacent in G. A diagonal is an edge
of G between two cycle vertices that are not consecutive in the cycle. -/
def HasOddCycleWithDiagonals {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) (d : â„•) : Prop :=
  âˆƒ (m : â„•) (f : Fin (2 * m + 3) â†’ V),
    Function.Injective f âˆ§
    (âˆ€ i : Fin (2 * m + 3),
      G.Adj (f i) (f âŸ¨(i.val + 1) % (2 * m + 3), Nat.mod_lt _ (by omega)âŸ©)) âˆ§
    d â‰¤ (Finset.univ.filter (fun p : Fin (2 * m + 3) Ã— Fin (2 * m + 3) =>
      p.1.val < p.2.val âˆ§
      G.Adj (f p.1) (f p.2) âˆ§
      p.2.val â‰  (p.1.val + 1) % (2 * m + 3) âˆ§
      p.1.val â‰  (p.2.val + 1) % (2 * m + 3))).card

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #1091, Part 1 (proved by Voss [Vo82]):

Let G be a Kâ‚„-free graph with chromatic number 4. Then G contains an odd cycle
with at least two diagonals.

ErdÅ‘s originally asked about one diagonal, proved by Larson [La79]. The
pentagonal wheel shows that three diagonals cannot be guaranteed.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_1091a (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n))
    (hK4 : G.CliqueFree 4) (hÏ‡ : G.chromaticNumber = (4 : â„•âˆ)) :
    HasOddCycleWithDiagonals G 2 :=
  sorry

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #1091, Part 2 (Open) [Er76c,p.4]:

Is there a function f : â„• â†’ â„• with f(r) â†’ âˆ such that every graph G with
chromatic number 4, in which every induced subgraph on â‰¤ r vertices has
chromatic number â‰¤ 3, contains an odd cycle with at least f(r) diagonals?
-/
theorem erdos_problem_1091b :
    âˆƒ f : â„• â†’ â„•, Tendsto f atTop atTop âˆ§
      âˆ€ (r n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)),
        G.chromaticNumber = (4 : â„•âˆ) â†’
        (âˆ€ S : Finset (Fin n), S.card â‰¤ r â†’
          (G.induce (â†‘S : Set (Fin n))).chromaticNumber â‰¤ (3 : â„•âˆ)) â†’
        HasOddCycleWithDiagonals G (f r) :=
  sorry

end Erdos1091

1â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
     3â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Continuum
     4â†’
     5â†’open Cardinal
     6â†’
     7â†’/-- The negative square-bracket partition relation Îº â†› [Î¼]â‚–Â² for cardinals.
     8â†’
     9â†’    There exists a k-coloring of pairs from a set of cardinality Îº such that
    10â†’    every subset of cardinality â‰¥ Î¼ contains pairs of all k colors.
    11â†’
    12â†’    In standard ErdÅ‘s-Rado partition calculus notation, this is Îº â†› [Î¼]â‚–Â². -/
    13â†’def NegSqBracketPartition (Îº Î¼ : Cardinal) (k : â„•) : Prop :=
    14â†’  âˆƒ (Î± : Type*) (_ : #Î± = Îº) (f : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Fin k),
    15â†’    (âˆ€ x y, f x y = f y x) âˆ§
    16â†’    âˆ€ (S : Set Î±), #S â‰¥ Î¼ â†’
    17â†’      âˆ€ c : Fin k, âˆƒ a âˆˆ S, âˆƒ b âˆˆ S, a â‰  b âˆ§ f a b = c
    18â†’
    19â†’/--
    20â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #474 (1954) [Er95d, p.64] [Va99, 7.81]:
    21â†’
    22â†’Does the negative square-bracket partition relation 2^â„µâ‚€ â†› [â„µâ‚]â‚ƒÂ² hold?
    23â†’In words: can the pairs from â„ be 3-colored so that every uncountable
    24â†’subset contains pairs of each color?
    25â†’
    26â†’Sierpinski and Kurepa independently proved the 2-color version (2^â„µâ‚€ â†› [â„µâ‚]â‚‚Â²)
    27â†’holds in ZFC. ErdÅ‘s proved that under the continuum hypothesis (ğ”  = â„µâ‚),
    28â†’the 3-color version holds, and offered $100 for deciding what happens without CH.
    29â†’
    30â†’Shelah [Sh88] showed it is consistent without CH that the positive relation
    31â†’2^â„µâ‚€ â†’ [â„µâ‚]â‚ƒÂ² holds, but with ğ”  very large.
    32â†’
    33â†’The specific remaining open question (asked in [Va99]):
    34â†’Assuming ğ”  = â„µâ‚‚, does 2^â„µâ‚€ â†› [â„µâ‚]â‚ƒÂ² hold?
    35â†’-/
    36â†’theorem erdos_problem_474 :
    37â†’    continuum = aleph 2 â†’
    38â†’    NegSqBracketPartition continuum (aleph 1) 3 :=
    39â†’  sorry
    40â†’

file.content:
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Basic
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Continuum

open Cardinal

/-- The negative square-bracket partition relation Îº â†› [Î¼]â‚–Â² for cardinals.

    There exists a k-coloring of pairs from a set of cardinality Îº such that
    every subset of cardinality â‰¥ Î¼ contains pairs of all k colors.

    In standard ErdÅ‘s-Rado partition calculus notation, this is Îº â†› [Î¼]â‚–Â². -/
def NegSqBracketPartition (Îº Î¼ : Cardinal) (k : â„•) : Prop :=
  âˆƒ (Î± : Type*) (_ : #Î± = Îº) (f : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Fin k),
    (âˆ€ x y, f x y = f y x) âˆ§
    âˆ€ (S : Set Î±), #S â‰¥ Î¼ â†’
      âˆ€ c : Fin k, âˆƒ a âˆˆ S, âˆƒ b âˆˆ S, a â‰  b âˆ§ f a b = c

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #474 (1954) [Er95d, p.64] [Va99, 7.81]:

Does the negative square-bracket partition relation 2^â„µâ‚€ â†› [â„µâ‚]â‚ƒÂ² hold?
In words: can the pairs from â„ be 3-colored so that every uncountable
subset contains pairs of each color?

Sierpinski and Kurepa independently proved the 2-color version (2^â„µâ‚€ â†› [â„µâ‚]â‚‚Â²)
holds in ZFC. ErdÅ‘s proved that under the continuum hypothesis (ğ”  = â„µâ‚),
the 3-color version holds, and offered $100 for deciding what happens without CH.

Shelah [Sh88] showed it is consistent without CH that the positive relation
2^â„µâ‚€ â†’ [â„µâ‚]â‚ƒÂ² holds, but with ğ”  very large.

The specific remaining open question (asked in [Va99]):
Assuming ğ”  = â„µâ‚‚, does 2^â„µâ‚€ â†› [â„µâ‚]â‚ƒÂ² hold?
-/
theorem erdos_problem_474 :
    continuum = aleph 2 â†’
    NegSqBracketPartition continuum (aleph 1) 3 :=
  sorry

1â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic
     3â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
     4â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Hom.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Cardinal SimpleGraph
     9â†’
    10â†’noncomputable section
    11â†’
    12â†’/-!
    13â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #597
    14â†’
    15â†’Let G be a graph on at most â„µâ‚ vertices which contains no Kâ‚„ and no K_{â„µâ‚€,â„µâ‚€}
    16â†’(the complete bipartite graph with â„µâ‚€ vertices in each class). Is it true that
    17â†’  Ï‰â‚Â² â†’ (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, G)Â²?
    18â†’
    19â†’Tags: graph theory, ramsey theory, set theory
    20â†’-/
    21â†’
    22â†’/-- The type of ordinals strictly less than Î±. -/
    23â†’abbrev OrdinalSet (Î± : Ordinal) := {a : Ordinal // a < Î±}
    24â†’
    25â†’/-- A graph G contains a complete bipartite subgraph K_{Îº,Îº} if there exist
    26â†’    disjoint vertex sets A and B, each of cardinality at least Îº,
    27â†’    such that every vertex in A is adjacent to every vertex in B. -/
    28â†’def SimpleGraph.ContainsBiclique {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) (Îº : Cardinal) : Prop :=
    29â†’  âˆƒ (A B : Set V), Disjoint A B âˆ§ #A â‰¥ Îº âˆ§ #B â‰¥ Îº âˆ§
    30â†’    âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆ€ b âˆˆ B, G.Adj a b
    31â†’
    32â†’/-- The ordinal-graph partition relation Î± â†’ (Î², G)Â²:
    33â†’    Every 2-coloring of ordered pairs from OrdinalSet Î± yields either:
    34â†’    - an order-embedded copy of Î² whose pairs are all colored 0, or
    35â†’    - a copy of G in the color-1 graph (an injective map preserving edges).
    36â†’
    37â†’    Here a "copy of Î²" is given by an order embedding e : OrdinalSet Î² â†ªo OrdinalSet Î±,
    38â†’    and monochromaticity means f (e i) (e j) = 0 for all i < j. A "copy of G"
    39â†’    is an injective map g : V â†’ OrdinalSet Î± such that every edge of G maps to
    40â†’    a pair colored 1. -/
    41â†’def OrdGraphPartition (Î± Î² : Ordinal) {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    42â†’  âˆ€ (f : OrdinalSet Î± â†’ OrdinalSet Î± â†’ Fin 2),
    43â†’    (âˆƒ e : OrdinalSet Î² â†ªo OrdinalSet Î±,
    44â†’      âˆ€ i j : OrdinalSet Î², i < j â†’ f (e i) (e j) = 0) âˆ¨
    45â†’    (âˆƒ g : V â†’ OrdinalSet Î±, Function.Injective g âˆ§
    46â†’      âˆ€ u v : V, G.Adj u v â†’ g u < g v â†’ f (g u) (g v) = 1)
    47â†’
    48â†’/--
    49â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #597 [Er87] [Va99, 7.84]:
    50â†’
    51â†’If G is a graph on at most â„µâ‚ vertices containing no Kâ‚„ and no K_{â„µâ‚€,â„µâ‚€},
    52â†’then Ï‰â‚Â² â†’ (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, G)Â².
    53â†’
    54â†’ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal proved that Ï‰â‚Â² â†’ (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, 3)Â². ErdÅ‘s originally asked this
    55â†’with just the assumption that G is Kâ‚„-free, but Baumgartner proved that
    56â†’Ï‰â‚Â² â†› (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, K_{â„µâ‚€,â„µâ‚€})Â².
    57â†’-/
    58â†’theorem erdos_problem_597 {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    59â†’    (hcard : #V â‰¤ aleph 1)
    60â†’    (hK4 : G.CliqueFree 4)
    61â†’    (hbip : Â¬G.ContainsBiclique (aleph 0)) :
    62â†’    OrdGraphPartition
    63â†’      ((aleph 1).ord ^ 2)
    64â†’      ((aleph 1).ord * (aleph 0).ord)
    65â†’      G :=
    66â†’  sorry
    67â†’
    68â†’end
    69â†’

file.content:
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Basic
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
import Mathlib.Order.Hom.Basic

open Cardinal SimpleGraph

noncomputable section

/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #597

Let G be a graph on at most â„µâ‚ vertices which contains no Kâ‚„ and no K_{â„µâ‚€,â„µâ‚€}
(the complete bipartite graph with â„µâ‚€ vertices in each class). Is it true that
  Ï‰â‚Â² â†’ (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, G)Â²?

Tags: graph theory, ramsey theory, set theory
-/

/-- The type of ordinals strictly less than Î±. -/
abbrev OrdinalSet (Î± : Ordinal) := {a : Ordinal // a < Î±}

/-- A graph G contains a complete bipartite subgraph K_{Îº,Îº} if there exist
    disjoint vertex sets A and B, each of cardinality at least Îº,
    such that every vertex in A is adjacent to every vertex in B. -/
def SimpleGraph.ContainsBiclique {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) (Îº : Cardinal) : Prop :=
  âˆƒ (A B : Set V), Disjoint A B âˆ§ #A â‰¥ Îº âˆ§ #B â‰¥ Îº âˆ§
    âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆ€ b âˆˆ B, G.Adj a b

/-- The ordinal-graph partition relation Î± â†’ (Î², G)Â²:
    Every 2-coloring of ordered pairs from OrdinalSet Î± yields either:
    - an order-embedded copy of Î² whose pairs are all colored 0, or
    - a copy of G in the color-1 graph (an injective map preserving edges).

    Here a "copy of Î²" is given by an order embedding e : OrdinalSet Î² â†ªo OrdinalSet Î±,
    and monochromaticity means f (e i) (e j) = 0 for all i < j. A "copy of G"
    is an injective map g : V â†’ OrdinalSet Î± such that every edge of G maps to
    a pair colored 1. -/
def OrdGraphPartition (Î± Î² : Ordinal) {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ (f : OrdinalSet Î± â†’ OrdinalSet Î± â†’ Fin 2),
    (âˆƒ e : OrdinalSet Î² â†ªo OrdinalSet Î±,
      âˆ€ i j : OrdinalSet Î², i < j â†’ f (e i) (e j) = 0) âˆ¨
    (âˆƒ g : V â†’ OrdinalSet Î±, Function.Injective g âˆ§
      âˆ€ u v : V, G.Adj u v â†’ g u < g v â†’ f (g u) (g v) = 1)

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #597 [Er87] [Va99, 7.84]:

If G is a graph on at most â„µâ‚ vertices containing no Kâ‚„ and no K_{â„µâ‚€,â„µâ‚€},
then Ï‰â‚Â² â†’ (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, G)Â².

ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal proved that Ï‰â‚Â² â†’ (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, 3)Â². ErdÅ‘s originally asked this
with just the assumption that G is Kâ‚„-free, but Baumgartner proved that
Ï‰â‚Â² â†› (Ï‰â‚Â·Ï‰, K_{â„µâ‚€,â„µâ‚€})Â².
-/
theorem erdos_problem_597 {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    (hcard : #V â‰¤ aleph 1)
    (hK4 : G.CliqueFree 4)
    (hbip : Â¬G.ContainsBiclique (aleph 0)) :
    OrdGraphPartition
      ((aleph 1).ord ^ 2)
      ((aleph 1).ord * (aleph 0).ord)
      G :=
  sorry

end

content.thinking:
Now I have a good understanding of the patterns. Let me formalize conjecture 1128.

The conjecture is:
Let $A, B, C$ be three sets of cardinality $\aleph_1$. Is it true that, in any 2-colouring of $A \times B \times C$, there must exist $A_1 \subset A$, $B_1 \subset B$, $C_1 \subset C$, all of cardinality $\aleph_0$, such that $A_1 \times B_1 \times C_1$ is monochromatic?


This was actually disproved by Prikry and Mills back in 1978, so I need to work with the negation insteadâ€”showing that there exists a 2-coloring of some $\aleph_1 \times \aleph_1 \times \aleph_1$ product where no countably infinite rectangular subproduct is monochromatic. I need to figure out which imports are necessary for this formalizationâ€”I'll need the cardinal arithmetic and aleph number definitions from Mathlib. Now I'm working through the precise statement: there exist sets A, B, C each with cardinality â„µâ‚ and a 2-coloring of their product such that no countably infinite subsets of each can form a monochromatic triple.

I'm deciding between stating the original conjecture and disproving it versus directly formalizing the negation as the true statement. Looking at how similar problems are structured, I should probably state what's actually true rather than what's false.

Now I'm writing the Lean code to formalize this ErdÅ‘s problem, importing the necessary cardinal arithmetic libraries and setting up the theorem statement with the proper cardinality constraints. I'm checking how cardinality works for sets in Mathlib â€” specifically whether `#Aâ‚` correctly interprets the cardinality of a `Set A` as the cardinality of its subtype, which should handle the definition properly. I think the standard approach in Mathlib is to use `Cardinal.mk` with the subtype coercion for sets. Looking at how other files handle this, I can just write `#S` directly and let the coercion work. But actually, I should reconsider my whole approachâ€”instead of existentially quantifying over types, I can just pick specific types with the cardinalities I need. Let me work with a single type of cardinality â„µâ‚ and write out the Lean code for this problem.

Writing Lean code... Formalizing the counterexample in Lean, setting up the theorem statement with three types of cardinality â„µâ‚ and a 2-coloring function, then asserting that no monochromatic subcubes of cardinality â„µâ‚€ exist in all three dimensions. I'm starting to think about universe level issues...

Actually, the universe levels should work out fine hereâ€”when we have `Î± : Type`, the cardinality `#Î±` lives in `Cardinal.{0}`, and `aleph 1` is also `Cardinal.{0}`, so everything should be consistent.

Now I'm thinking through the syntax for `#â†¥A` where `A` is a set. The subtype `â†¥A` is a `Type` in the same universe as the underlying type, so its cardinality should match up with `aleph 0` without any universe issues.

Let me try a cleaner formulation...

Writing Lean code... Writing the theorem statement... I'm setting up the Lean formalization with the necessary imports and opening the Cardinal namespace, then writing out the problem statement for ErdÅ‘s Problem #1128 about colorings of products of three sets with cardinality â„µâ‚. Formalizing the theorem statement...

The original conjecture claims that for any sets A, B, C of cardinality â„µâ‚ and any 2-coloring of their product, we can find countably infinite subsets whose product is monochromatic. But the negationâ€”which is actually provableâ€”shows there exist sets of that size and a coloring where no such monochromatic subproduct exists.

Let me verify the problem statement: it's asking whether this holds for *any* choice of A, B, C with cardinality â„µâ‚, so my formalization is right. And since all three sets have the same cardinality, I should think about whether that symmetry matters for the construction.

For the Lean formalization, I need to be careful with cardinality notationâ€”`#â†¥Aâ‚` gives me the cardinality of the subtype, which is what I need to check against â„µâ‚. I'm confirming that `#S` works directly for sets in Lean based on the existing code examples, so I can use the cleaner `#Aâ‚` syntax instead of the more verbose `#â†¥Aâ‚`. Now I'm writing out the final version with the necessary imports and the cardinal notation. Now I'm formalizing this in Lean, setting up the theorem statement that captures the counterexampleâ€”three sets of cardinality â„µâ‚ with a 2-coloring of their product where no monochromatic subcube of countable size exists.

I'm checking how cardinality works with sets in Lean's type system, specifically whether `Cardinal.mk` properly handles the coercion from `Set Î±` to its underlying type via the subtype construction.

Now I'm verifying that the universe levels are consistent throughoutâ€”since we're working with `Type 0` and `aleph 1` is also at `Cardinal.{0}`, everything should align properly, though I need to be careful about where the existential quantification lives in the type hierarchy.

I could formalize this using specific types like ordinals below `aleph 1`, but the existential approach feels cleaner and more aligned with how this codebase typically handles these proofs. Let me start writing the actual file and double-check the monochromatic condition as I go.

Verifying the quantification structure...

Now I'm reconsidering the cardinality constraintâ€”the problem specifies exactly â„µâ‚€ (countably infinite), not just countable, so `#Aâ‚ = aleph 0` is the right interpretation. I should double-check whether the original conjecture might have intended a different cardinality bound, though the wording seems clear. I'm realizing the logical structure hereâ€”if the original conjecture uses "at least â„µâ‚€", then the negation with "exactly â„µâ‚€" actually strengthens the statement, since proving no countable sub-products exist automatically rules out uncountable ones too. But I need to be careful about the quantifier direction: negating "there exists Aâ‚ of cardinality â„µâ‚€ with property P" gives "for all Aâ‚ of cardinality â„µâ‚€, not P", and if I switch to "â‰¥ â„µâ‚€" in the negation, I'm claiming something stronger about all infinite cardinalities.

Since any infinite set contains a countably infinite subset, both formulations end up equivalent for this problemâ€”the disproof applies to all infinite sub-products, not just countable ones. I'll stick with "exactly â„µâ‚€" to match the problem's language and keep things straightforward.

Let me finalize the disproof statement: I need sets A, B, C of cardinality â„µâ‚ and a 2-coloring where for every countably infinite subset triple, the product isn't monochromatic.

Now I'm working through the type-theoretic detailsâ€”specifically that the cardinality of a countable subset lives in the same universe as the original type, so the equality with aleph 0 is well-formed.

I'm deciding between using the cardinal notation versus the natural number approach, and the cardinal approach is clearly the right choice here since we're dealing with infinite cardinalities.

Writing the Lean formalization... Finishing the theorem statement that formalizes the counterexample to ErdÅ‘s's conjecture, showing that there exists a 2-coloring of a product of three â„µâ‚-sized sets where no monochromatic subset of the required cardinality can be found.

Now I have a good understanding of the patterns. Let me formalize conjecture 1128.

The problem asks: Let A, B, C be three sets of cardinality â„µâ‚. In any 2-colouring of AÃ—BÃ—C, must there exist countably infinite subsets Aâ‚âŠ‚A, Bâ‚âŠ‚B, Câ‚âŠ‚C such that Aâ‚Ã—Bâ‚Ã—Câ‚ is monochromatic? This was **disproved** by Prikry and Mills, so I'll formalize the negation (the true statement).

input.content:
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Basic
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph

open Cardinal

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #1128 (Disproved) [Er81b,p.33]:

A problem of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal. Let A, B, C be three sets of cardinality â„µâ‚.
Is it true that, in any 2-colouring of A Ã— B Ã— C, there must exist
Aâ‚ âŠ‚ A, Bâ‚ âŠ‚ B, Câ‚ âŠ‚ C, all of cardinality â„µâ‚€, such that
Aâ‚ Ã— Bâ‚ Ã— Câ‚ is monochromatic?

The answer is no. This was disproved by Prikry and Mills in 1978
(unpublished), as reported by TodorÄeviÄ‡ and KomjÃ¡th.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_1128 :
    âˆƒ (Î± Î² Î³ : Type) (_ : #Î± = aleph 1) (_ : #Î² = aleph 1) (_ : #Î³ = aleph 1)
      (f : Î± Ã— Î² Ã— Î³ â†’ Fin 2),
      âˆ€ (Aâ‚ : Set Î±) (Bâ‚ : Set Î²) (Câ‚ : Set Î³),
        #Aâ‚ = aleph 0 â†’ #Bâ‚ = aleph 0 â†’ #Câ‚ = aleph 0 â†’
        Â¬âˆƒ c : Fin 2, âˆ€ a âˆˆ Aâ‚, âˆ€ b âˆˆ Bâ‚, âˆ€ x âˆˆ Câ‚, f (a, b, x) = c :=
  sorry

Build succeeded. The only warning is the expected `sorry` declaration for the conjecture.

Here's a summary of the formalization:

**Conjecture 1128** â€” A problem of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal, disproved by Prikry and Mills (1978).

The original question asked whether for any three sets A, B, C of cardinality â„µâ‚, every 2-colouring of AÃ—BÃ—C must contain a monochromatic countably infinite sub-product Aâ‚Ã—Bâ‚Ã—Câ‚. Since this was **disproved**, the theorem states the negation: there exist sets of cardinality â„µâ‚ and a 2-colouring such that no countably infinite sub-product is monochromatic.

The formalization in `conjectures/1128.lean` uses:
- `Cardinal.aleph 1` for â„µâ‚ (the cardinality of the ambient sets)
- `Cardinal.aleph 0` for â„µâ‚€ (the cardinality of the sought subsets)
- Existential quantification over types Î±, Î², Î³ and a coloring `f : Î± Ã— Î² Ã— Î³ â†’ Fin 2`
- Universal quantification over all subsets of cardinality â„µâ‚€, asserting none yields a monochromatic sub-product
